p: Survey respondents were asked to identify the relative importance of climate and non-climate risk factors in triggering epidemics of diseases transmitted by Ae. aegypti ( Table 4). Non-climate risk factors were identified as more important overall than climate risk factors. The key non-climate risk factors, in order of importance (% very important or important), were the introduction of new viruses (100%), water storage (97%), human movement (91%), limited community engagement (91%), insecticide resistance (88%), and insufficient resources (88%). Climate risk factors, in order of importance (% very important or important), were heavy rainfall (91%), El Niño or La Niña events (72%), drought conditions (56%) and warm air temperatures (51%).
